content.user_title: Implement Structured Logging with Wide Events
content.value_statement: Traditional scattered log statements make debugging difficult and lack context. This guide teaches you to emit one comprehensive event per request with all debugging context included.
actual_capabilities: Explains wide event logging pattern with single event per request
Provides comprehensive field reference for different contexts
Shows anti-patterns to avoid in logging implementation
Includes SQL query examples for log analysis
Demonstrates middleware pattern for request tracking
limitations: Documentation only - no automated logging implementation
Requires manual integration into existing codebases
Field examples focus on web applications and e-commerce
Assumes familiarity with basic logging concepts

use_cases.title: Improve production debugging
use_cases.description: Replace scattered log statements with contextual wide events that contain all request information in a single searchable record.

use_cases.title: Enhance observability pipeline
use_cases.description: Implement structured logging that enables powerful queries and analysis in log management platforms like Elasticsearch or Splunk.

use_cases.title: Standardize logging practices
use_cases.description: Establish consistent logging patterns across your team with high-cardinality fields for effective debugging and monitoring.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Implementation
prompt_templates.scenario: Adding structured logging to a Node.js API
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me implement wide event logging for my Express API. Show me how to create a middleware that builds context throughout the request and emits one comprehensive log event at the end.

prompt_templates.title: Error Context
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to log payment failures with complete context. Show me how to structure an error log that includes user info, cart details, payment attempts, and error codes in a single event.

prompt_templates.title: Performance Tracking
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me add performance metrics to my wide events. I want to track database queries, external API calls, and cache hits with proper timing breakdowns.

prompt_templates.title: Query Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me SQL queries to analyze my structured logs. I want to find slow requests for enterprise customers, payment failure patterns, and feature flag performance impacts.

output_examples.input: Create a structured log for a failed payment attempt
output: Wide event with request ID, user details (ID, subscription tier, lifetime value), cart information (items, total, currency), payment details (provider, method, attempts, latency), and error context (type, code, message, retriable flag)
All fields nested in appropriate objects for easy querying
Single log entry containing everything needed for debugging

best_practices: Build context throughout request lifecycle, emit once in finally block
Include high-cardinality fields like user_id and request_id for debugging
Use consistent snake_case naming and appropriate data types
Avoid logging sensitive data like passwords or full credit card numbers
anti_patterns: String concatenation logs that lose structure and queryability
Scattered log statements spread across multiple lines
Low-cardinality only logs that can't identify specific users or requests
Missing business context that makes debugging impossible

faq.question: Which logging libraries support wide events?
faq.answer: Any structured logging library works: Winston, Pino, Bunyan for Node.js; Logrus, Zap for Go; SLF4J with JSON layout for Java. The pattern is language-agnostic.

faq.question: How many fields should a wide event contain?
faq.answer: Include 50+ fields for high-dimensionality. Don't worry about size - storage is cheap, debugging time is expensive. Include all context that might help debugging.

faq.question: Should I log wide events in development too?
faq.answer: Yes, use the same pattern everywhere. In development, set log level to debug to see more events. In production, sample debug logs but always log info/error.

faq.question: How do I handle sensitive data in logs?
faq.answer: Exclude passwords, tokens, and full PII. For necessary data like emails, consider hashing. Always review what you're logging before including user data.

faq.question: What's the difference between trace_id and request_id?
faq.answer: request_id identifies one request in one service. trace_id spans multiple services in distributed systems. Use both for correlating requests across microservices.

faq.question: How do I query wide events effectively?
faq.answer: Use structured log platforms like Elasticsearch or Splunk. Query by specific field values, aggregate by dimensions, and filter by time ranges for powerful analysis.
